Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course is a FANTASTIC introduction to "expertise." I've come away from this seminar with so many essential readings under my belt, familiarity with different schools of thought and approaches to expertise, as well as a good understanding of both the sociological foundations of the "expertise" discourse as well as its very political applications.

I had never previously thought of expertise as being something other than being highly knowledge in a certain topic. However, expertise is so much more than that. The class made me reevaluate what I thought of as expertise and how I view the role of experts.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The course was incredibly well-structured and well-organized, and class discussions were usually very productive and insightful. 

There weren't any major weaknesses, but I think it might be wise to adjust the grading schematic a bit. The final essay is weighted quite heavily considering that it is the only piece of writing that we had to submit throughout the duration of the course. If the final essay is to remain as heavily-weighted as it is, I think it would be a good idea to incorporate some smaller writing assignments throughout the semester.
This course could not be improved. 10/10

Strengths: The small class (9 people) was amazing for class discussion! Everyone had the opportunity to say their opinions and perspectives and it always felt very collaborative. I also enjoyed that before discussion began we would all go around and say what we thought about the week's readings and explain what we were confused about, disliked, etc. Doing that especially helped me in weeks where the reading were a bit confusing. 

Weaknesses: I honestly found no strong weakness

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yeah! I liked it so much

Yes absolutely! This is my favorite PLSC course that I've taken so far, partially because there is so much sociology that complements the political science as well. Expertise is in crisis; we see it in climate denial, anti-vaccine rhetoric, and then Lord Chancellor Michael Gove's famous justification of Brexit, "the people of this country have had enough of experts." This course is so relevant in today's political landscape, and the way the seminar is structured really helps to dig deep into the subject. Professor Brandmayr is brilliant and very engaging, and the readings were all captivating.
I would highly recommend! The topic is not only very interesting but it is so relevant to today's time when we've depended a lot on experts.
